thread.title: Cape football gets whacked at Sussex Central homecoming 34-7
thread.title_full: Cape football gets whacked at Sussex Central homecoming 34-7

author: newsroom@capegazette.com (Dave Frederick )
title: Cape football gets whacked at Sussex Central homecoming 34-7
text:
Cape football gets whacked at Sussex Central homecoming 34-7 By Dave Frederick | Oct 13, 2015 Photo by: Dan Cook Cape running back Michael Williams, center, follows the block by Jeremiah Smack, left, and Brent Reed in the Golden Knights' win over the Vikings. 
Cape football lost ugly at Central’s homecoming Oct. 10 34-7 in a performance so mysteriously bad and uninspired that no one coach or player could take full responsibility. 
“I’ve been around this deal a long time and so has [Central's coach] John Wells," said Cape’s Bill Collick. "I know when that Sturgis kid gets into the second level somebody better tackle him, and I know with the backs we have we should be able to run the football.” 
KiAnte Sturgis had enough yards in the game to run halfway back to Indian River, amassing 248 yards and three touchdowns on just seven carries. 
The Knights came into the game having lost three consecutive games to Interboro, Queen Anne’s and Sussex Tech. 
Cape had beaten up on Cape May, Indian River and Polytech a combined 122-8 while losing game two of the season to Oakdale of Maryland 48-12. 
Sturgis broke a pair of wing-T sweep right plays in the second quarter on runs of 79 and 80 yards as the Knights led 15-0. 
Sturgis later dropped a punt (the least he could do) and Cape recovered at midfield. Quarterback Dillon Adam hit Robbie Neall on a long throw and catch down inside the 5-yard line where Kolbi Wright ran it in three yards for a touchdown. The Richard Carey kick made it 15-7 with 1:09 left to play in the first half. 
And then to quote the late Gonzo journalist Hunter Thompson, “When the going gets weird, the weird turn pro.” 
A short kick spinning like a top toward the Central sidelines was scooped up by Kendrique Nocks who stayed true through defensive traffic before busting loose for a 68-yard touchdown run. 
Nocks became a “Knock Knock” no joke in the Cape end zone when he intercepted a Dillon Adams pass on the next possession and returned it 50 yards for his second touchdown in 25 seconds without playing offense, some kind of homecoming record for certain. 
Sturgis scored again on a 67-yard run on his first touch of the third quarter to give the Knights a 34-7 lead. 
Cape dropped to 3-2 on the nine-game schedule and will host Dover (3-2) Friday, Oct. 16. Cape linebacker Jeremiah Smack blitzes past KiAnte Sturgis to put pressure on Knights quarterback William Wells. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape running back Rasheed Woods drags a Central tackler for a short gain. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape punter Zach Dale gets off a kick during a heavy Central rush. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape running back Jeremiah Smack dives forward for an extra yard. (Photo by: Dan Cook) The Cape defense swarms on Central ball carrier Timothy Jones. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape's Derrick Wilson, right, blocks Central's Christian Moore. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape quarterback Dillon Adams waits for a play called from the sideline. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Head coach Bill Collick isn't happy with his team's performance. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape's running back Kolbi Wright smashes through the Central defense. (Photo by: Dan Cook) Cape running back Jeremiah Smack throws a halfback pass.
